images.title: Saffron in bloom
images.caption: Saffron in bloom
images.desc: It’s harvest time for saffron, the precious seasoning that’s mostly grown in Iran but is used in cuisines around the world. Saffron is derived from the saffron crocus, an autumn-flowering plant with purple petals as richly hued as the vivid crimson stigmas (called threads) in the centre of the bloom. These threads are carefully extracted by hand with tweezers and dried before they’re used for cooking. Each flower comes with just three threads, and it takes a lot of them - roughly 75,000 crocuses will yield just one pound of saffron. The entire harvest can last only about a week or two, because of the short life of the saffron crocus bloom.
